children.value: In this section we will examine the disassembly of a simple C program that adds two integers. The program is compiled for the i386 architecture, which is a 32-bit architecture commonly used in older computers and embedded systems. The disassembly will help us understand how the C code translates into assembly instructions, and how these instructions are executed by the CPU.
Compilation of the C Program to Produce Assembly Code and Object Code

children.label: Compilation of the C Program to Produce Assembly Code and Object Code

children.value: The C program is compiled using the GCC compiler with the
flag to specify the i386 architecture. The
flag creates assembly code in the Intel format. The
flag generates assembly code, the -fverbose-asm flag includes C source code in the assembly code, and the
flag compiles the assembly code into an object file.

gcc --sysroot=/ -m32 -masm=intel -S -fverbose-asm add_int.c -o add_int.s
gcc --sysroot=/ -m32 -c add_int.s -o add_int.o
The assembly code is in Intel syntax, which is commonly used for x86 assembly language.

.file	"add_int.c"
	.intel_syntax noprefix
# GNU C17 (conda-forge gcc 14.2.0-2) version 14.2.0 (x86_64-conda-linux-gnu)
#	compiled by GNU C version 14.2.0, GMP version 6.2.1, MPFR version 4.1.0, MPC version 1.2.1, isl version isl-0.24-GMP

# GGC heuristics: --param ggc-min-expand=100 --param ggc-min-heapsize=131072
# options passed: -m32 -masm=intel -mtune=generic -march=x86-64
	.text
	.globl	main
	.type	main, @function
main:
.LFB0:
	.cfi_startproc
	push	ebp	#
	.cfi_def_cfa_offset 8
	.cfi_offset 5, -8
	mov	ebp, esp	#,
	.cfi_def_cfa_register 5
	sub	esp, 16	#,
	call	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax	#
	add	eax, OFFSET FLAT:_GLOBAL_OFFSET_TABLE_	# tmp98,
# add_int.c:7: 	a = 1;
	mov	DWORD PTR -4[ebp], 1	# a,
# add_int.c:8: 	b = 9;
	mov	DWORD PTR -8[ebp], 9	# b,
# add_int.c:10: 	c = a + b;
	mov	edx, DWORD PTR -4[ebp]	# tmp105, a
	mov	eax, DWORD PTR -8[ebp]	# tmp106, b
	add	eax, edx	# c_3, tmp105
	mov	DWORD PTR -12[ebp], eax	# c, c_3
	mov	eax, 0	# _4,
# add_int.c:11: }
	leave	
	.cfi_restore 5
	.cfi_def_cfa 4, 4
	ret	
	.cfi_endproc
.LFE0:
	.size	main, .-main
	.section	.text.__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax,"axG",@progbits,__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax,comdat
	.globl	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax
	.hidden	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax
	.type	__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax, @function
__x86.get_pc_thunk.ax:
.LFB1:
	.cfi_startproc
	mov	eax, DWORD PTR [esp]	#,
	ret
	.cfi_endproc
.LFE1:
	.ident	"GCC: (conda-forge gcc 14.2.0-2) 14.2.0"
	.section	.note.GNU-stack,"",@progbits
The attached file is an assembly code file (
). It is written in Intel syntax and compiled for a 32-bit architecture (
) using GCC 14.2.0. Below is a detailed explanation of the code:
: Indicates that this assembly file was generated from the C source file
The file was compiled using GCC 14.2.0 with the
are used for garbage collection optimization during compilation.
) is defined as a global symbol (
) and is marked as a function (
The prologue sets up the stack frame for the function:
: Saves the base pointer of the previous stack frame.
: Allocates 16 bytes of space on the stack for local variables.
: Calls a helper function to get the program counter (PC).
: Adjusts the PC to point to the Global Offset Table (GOT), used for position-independent code.
The C code initializes three variables (
: Sets the return value of the function to
The epilogue restores the stack frame:
: Restores the previous base pointer and stack pointer.
This function is used to retrieve the program counter (PC) for position-independent code:
: Loads the return address (PC) from the stack into
Contains metadata about the compiler version:
Indicates that the stack is not executable (a security feature).
This assembly code represents a simple C program that initializes two integers (
. The code includes standard prologue and epilogue for stack management and uses a helper function for position-independent code.
The object file is linked to create an executable file using the
The executable file is disassembled using the

objdump -x -D -s -t -Mintel add_int.o > objdump_of_dot_o.txt
objdump -x -D -s -t -Mintel add_int_C_i386 > objdump_of_dot_exe.txt

This object code disassembly represents the compiled output of a C program for the i386 architecture. Below is an explanation of the key sections and their significance:

add_int.o:     file format elf32-i386
architecture: i386, flags 0x00000011:
HAS_RELOC, HAS_SYMS
start address 0x00000000
indicates the ELF (Executable and Linkable Format) for the 32-bit i386 architecture.
: The file contains a symbol table.
: The starting address of the program is

Marks the stack as non-executable for security purposes.
Contains exception handling information for stack unwinding.
